[[File:Vereenigde Oostindische Compagnie spiegelretourschip Amsterdam replica.jpg|thumb|right|Replica of an [[East Indiaman]] of the [[Dutch East India Company]]/United East India Company ([[Verenigde Oostindische Compagnie|VOC]]). The VOC is often considered by many to be the world's first formally [[listing (finance)|listed]] [[public company]] and the first historical model of the multinational corporation (or [[#transnational corporation|transnational corporation]]) in its modern sense.<ref>[[Timothy Brook|Brook, Timothy]]: ''[[Vermeer's Hat|Vermeer's Hat: The Seventeenth Century and the Dawn of the Global World]]''. (Bloomsbury Press, 2008, pp. 288, {{ISBN|978-1596915992}})</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lrb.co.uk/v23/n07/murray-sayle/japan-goes-dutch |title=Japan goes Dutch |publisher=[[London Review of Books]], Vol. 23 No. 7 |author=[[Murray Sayle|Sayle, Murray]] |quote=[[Murray Sayle]]: "The Netherlands United East Indies Company (Verenigde Oostindische Compagnie, or VOC), founded in 1602, was the world's first multinational, joint-stock, limited liability corporation – as well as its first government-backed trading cartel. [[British East India Company|Our own East India Company]], founded in 1600, remained a coffee-house clique until 1657, when it, too, began selling shares, not in individual voyages, but in the Company itself, by which time its Dutch rival was by far the biggest commercial enterprise the world had known." |date=5 April 2001 |accessdate=13 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/roadshow/fts/corpuschristi_201205A19.html |author=Phelan, Ben |title=Dutch East India Company: The World's First Multinational |publisher=[[PBS.org]] |date=7 Jan 2013 |accessdate=8 August 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www2.deloitte.com/insights/us/en/topics/innovation/institutional-innovation.html |author=Hagel, John; Brown, John Seely |title=Institutional Innovation: Creating Smarter Organizations |publisher=[[Deloitte|Deloitte Insights]] |quote=[[John Hagel III|John Hagel]] & [[John Seely Brown]] (2013): "[...] In 1602, the Dutch East India Company was formed. It was a new type of institution: the first multinational company, and the first to issue public stock. These innovations allowed a single company to mobilize financial resources from a large number of investors and create ventures at a scale that had previously only been possible for monarchs." |date=12 March 2013 |accessdate=14 August 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/rise-and-fall-of-united-east-india-2013-11 |author= Taylor, Bryan |title=The Rise and Fall of the Largest Corporation in History |publisher=[[BusinessInsider.com]] |date=6 Nov 2013 |accessdate=8 August 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.middlewisconsin.org/corporate-colonization-of-wisconsin-part-4/ |author=Roberts, Keith |title=Corporate Colonization of Wisconsin, Part IV — The Dutch East India Company and the Koch Wisconsin Company |publisher=MiddleWisconsin.org |date=15 March 2015 |accessdate=25 May 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://moneyweek.com/20-march-1602-dutch-east-india-company-formed/ |author=Partridge, Matthew |title=This day in history: 20 March 1602: Dutch East India Company formed |publisher=MoneyWeek.com |date=20 March 2015 |accessdate=20 May 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lowyinstitute.org/the-interpreter/starting-point-first-global-supply-chain |author=Grenville, Stephen |title=The first global supply chain |publisher=[[Lowy Institute]] |date=3 November 2017 |accessdate=28 May 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.finfacts.ie/Irish_finance_news/articleDetail.php?First-Modern-Economy-Myths-on-tulips-most-valuable-firm-in-history-831 |author=Hennigan, Michael |title=First Modern Economy: Myths on tulips & most valuable firm in history |publisher=Finfacts.ie (Irish Finance and Business Portal) |date=22 January 2018 |accessdate=22 May 2018 }}</ref>]] A '''multinational corporation''' ('''MNC''') or '''worldwide enterprise''' <ref name="pitelis">{{cite book |last= Pitelis |first= Christos |title= The nature of the transnational firm |author2=Roger Sugden |year= 2000 |publisher= Routledge |location= |isbn= 0-415-16787-6 |page= H72 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=mXjeiQYR088C&printse}}</ref> is a [[corporation|corporate]] [[organization]] which owns or controls production of goods or services in at least one country other than its home country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.econ.iastate.edu/classes/econ355/choi/mul.htm|title=Multinational Corporations|publisher=}}</ref> [[Black's Law Dictionary]] suggests that a company or group should be considered a multinational corporation if it derives 25% or more of its revenue from out-of-home-country operations.<ref>[https://thelawdictionary.org/multinational-corporation-mnc/ What is MULTINATIONAL CORPORATION (MNC)?], accessed 18 August 2018</ref> A multinational corporation can also be referred to as a '''multinational enterprise''' ('''MNE'''), a '''transnational enterprise''' ('''TNE'''), a '''transnational corporation''' ('''TNC'''), an '''international corporation''', or a '''stateless corporation'''.<ref>Roy D. Voorhees, Emerson L. Seim, and John I. Coppett, "Global Logistics and Stateless Corporations," ''Transportation Practitioners Journal'' 59, 2 (Winter 1992): 144-51.</ref> There are subtle but real differences between these three labels, as well as multinational corporation and worldwide enterprise.
Most of the largest and most influential companies of the modern age are publicly traded multinational corporations, including ''[[Forbes Global 2000]]'' companies. Multinational corporations are subject to [[#Criticism|criticisms]] for lacking [[ethics|ethical standards]], and that this shows up in how they evade ethical laws and leverage their own business agenda with capital, and even the military backing of their own wealthy host nation-states.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} They have also become associated with [[multinational tax haven]]s and [[base erosion and profit shifting]] tax avoidance activities.
==Overview== [[File:Toyota Headquarter Toyota City.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Toyota is one of the world's largest multinational corporation(s) with their headquarters in Toyota City, Japan. |[[Toyota]] is one of the world's largest multinational corporations with their headquarters in [[Toyota City]], [[Japan]].]] A multinational corporation (MNC) is usually a large corporation incorporated in one country which produces or sells goods or services in various countries.<ref>{{cite book|last=Doob|first=Christopher M.|title=Social Inequality and Social Stratification in US Society|year=2013|publisher=Pearson Education Inc}}</ref> The two main characteristics of MNCs are their large size and the fact that their worldwide activities are centrally controlled by the parent companies.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://trcollege.net/study-material/24-economics/47-role-of-multinational-corporations |title=Role of Multinational Corporations |publisher=[[T. Romana College]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161127054055/http://trcollege.net/study-material/24-economics/47-role-of-multinational-corporations |archive-date=27 November 2016 |access-date=3 January 2018}}</ref> * [[Import]]ing and [[export]]ing goods and services * Making significant investments in a foreign country * Buying and selling licenses in foreign markets * Engaging in [[contract manufacturing]] — permitting a local manufacturer in a foreign country to produce their products * Opening manufacturing facilities or assembly operations in foreign countries
MNCs may gain from their global presence in a variety of ways. First of all, MNCs can benefit from the [[economy of scale]] by spreading [[R&D]] expenditures and advertising costs over their global sales, pooling global purchasing power over suppliers, and utilizing their technological and managerial know-how globally with minimal additional costs. Furthermore, MNCs can use their global presence to take advantage of underpriced labor services available in certain developing countries, and gain access to special R&D capabilities residing in advanced foreign countries.<ref>{{cite book|last=Eun|first=Cheol S.|last2=Resnick|first2=Bruce G.|title=International Financial Management,6th Edition|year=2013|publisher=Beijing Chengxin Weiye Printing Inc}}</ref>
The problem of moral and legal constraints upon the behavior of multinational corporations, given that they are effectively "stateless" actors, is one of several urgent global [[socioeconomic]] problems that emerged during the late twentieth century.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Koenig-Archibugi|first1=Mathias|title=Transnational Corporations and Public Accountability|journal=Gary 2004|page=106|url=http://dspace.africaportal.org/jspui/bitstream/123456789/8719/1/Transnational%20Corporations%20and%20Public%20Accountability.pdf?1|accessdate=2 February 2015}} {{cite news|last1=Krugman|first1=Paul|title=In Praise of Cheap Labor: Bad Jobs at Bad Wages Are Better than No Jobs at All|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/business/the_dismal_science/1997/03/in_praise_of_cheap_labor.html|accessdate=2 February 2015|agency=Slate|date=20 March 1997}}</ref>
Potentially, the best concept for analyzing society's governance limitations over modern corporations is the concept of "stateless corporations". Coined at least as early as 1990 in ''[[Business Week]]'', the conception was theoretically clarified in 1992: that an empirical strategy for defining a stateless corporation is with analytical tools at the intersection between [[demographic]] analysis and [[transportation]] research. This intersection is known as [[logistics|logistics management]], and it describes the importance of rapidly increasing global mobility of resources. In a long history of analysis of multinational corporations we are some quarter century into an era of stateless corporations - corporations which meet the realities of the needs of source materials on a worldwide basis and to produce and customize products for individual countries.<ref>Holstein, William J. et al., "The Stateless Corporation", ''Business Week'' (May 14, 1990), p. 98. Roy D. Voorhees, Emerson L. Seim, and John I. Coppett, "Global Logistics and Stateless Corporations", ''Transportation Practitioners Journal'' 59, 2 (Winter 1992): 144-51.</ref>
One of the first multinational business organizations, the [[East India Company]], was established in 1600.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://yaleglobal.yale.edu/about/globalinc.jsp |title=GlobalInc. An Atlas of The Multinational Corporation" Medard Gabel & Henry Bruner, New York: The New Press, 2003. ISBN 1-56584-727-X |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20031222070819/http://yaleglobal.yale.edu/about/globalinc.jsp |archivedate=2003-12-22 |df= }}</ref> After the East India Company, came the [[Dutch East India Company]], founded March 20, 1602, which would become the largest company in the world for nearly 200 years.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kb.nl/themas/geschiedenis-en-cultuur/koloniaal-verleden/voc-1602-1799 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-07-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150207085730/http://www.kb.nl/themas/geschiedenis-en-cultuur/koloniaal-verleden/voc-1602-1799 |archivedate=2015-02-07 |df= }}</ref>
The main characteristics of multinational companies are: * In general, there is a national strength of large companies as the main body, in the way of foreign direct investment or acquire local enterprises, established [[subsidiaries]] or branches in many countries; * It usually has a complete [[decision-making]] system and the highest decision-making center, each subsidiary or branch has its own decision-making body, according to their different features and operations to make decisions, but its decision must be subordinated to the highest decision-making center; * MNCs seek markets in worldwide and rational production layout, professional fixed-point production, fixed-point sales products, in order to achieve [[profit maximization|maximum profit]]; * Due to strong economic and technical strength, with fast information transmission, as well as funding for rapid cross-border transfers, the multinational has stronger [[Competition (companies)|competitiveness]] in the world; * Many large multinational companies have varying degrees of monopoly in some area, due to economic and technical strength or production advantages.
== Legal domicile == Multinational corporations can select from a variety of jurisdictions for various subsidiaries, but the ultimate parent company can select a single [[Domicile (law)|legal domicile]]; as of 2014, the Netherlands has been a popular choice, as it has fewer requirements for meetings, compensation, and audit committees.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/business/2014/02/24/here-there-and-everywhere|title=Here, there and everywhere|work=The Economist|access-date=2018-11-25|language=en}}</ref> As of 2014, [[Great Britain]] had advantages due to laws on withholding dividends and a double-taxation treaty with the [[United States]].<ref name=":0" />
Corporations can legally engage in [[tax avoidance]] through their jurisdiction, but must be careful to avoid illegal [[tax evasion]].
== Regulation == Multinational corporations may be subject to the laws and regulations of both their domicile and the additional jurisdictions where they are engaged in business.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Phillip|first=Blumberg,|date=1990|title=The Corporate Entity in an Era of Multinational Corporations|url=https://opencommons.uconn.edu/law_papers/58/|journal=OpenCommons@UConn|language=en}}</ref> In some cases, the jurisdiction can help to avoid burdensome laws, but regulatory statutes often target the "enterprise" with statutory language around "control".<ref name=":1" />
== Alternatives and arrangements == For small corporations, registering a foreign subsidiary can be expensive and complex, involving fees, signatures, and forms;<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://velocityglobal.com/blog/foreign-subsidiary-10-reasons-you-should-not-create-one/|title=10 Reasons You Should Not Create a Foreign Subsidiary|last=|first=|date=2015-07-17|work=Velocity Global|access-date=2018-11-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181125233947/https://velocityglobal.com/blog/foreign-subsidiary-10-reasons-you-should-not-create-one/|archive-date=2018-11-25|dead-url=no|language=en-US}}</ref> a [[professional employer organization]] (PEO) is sometimes advertised as a cheaper and simpler alternative,<ref name=":2" /> but not all jurisdictions have laws accepting these types of arrangements.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.china-briefing.com/news/outsourcing-options-fdi-china/|title=Outsourcing Options for FDI into China - China Briefing News|last=|first=|date=2017-07-12|work=China Briefing News|access-date=2018-11-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181125234243/http://www.china-briefing.com/news/outsourcing-options-fdi-china/|archive-date=2018-11-25|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Dispute resolution and arbitration == {{Further|International legal system}} Disputes between corporations in different nations is often handled through [[international arbitration]].
==Theoretical background== The actions of multinational corporations are strongly supported by [[economic liberalism]] and [[free market]] system in a [[globalized]] international society. According to the economic realist view, individuals act in rational ways to maximize their self-interest and therefore, when individuals act rationally, markets are created and they function best in free market system where there is little government interference. As a result, international wealth is maximized with free exchange of goods and services.<ref>{{cite book |title= Essentials of international relations |last= Mingst |first= Karen A. |authorlink= |year= 2014 |publisher= W. W. Norton & Company |location= |isbn= 978-0-393-92195-3 |page= 310 |url= }}</ref>
To many economic liberals, multinational corporations are the vanguard of the liberal order.<ref>{{cite book |title= Essentials of international relations |last= Mingst |first= Karen A. |authorlink= |year= 2014 |publisher= W. W. Norton & Company |location= |isbn= 978-0-393-92195-3 |page= 311 |url= }}</ref> They are the embodiment par excellence of the liberal ideal of an interdependent world economy. They have taken the integration of national economies beyond trade and money to the internationalization of production. For the first time in history, production, marketing, and investment are being organized on a global scale rather than in terms of isolated national economies.<ref name="Gilpin">{{cite book |title= Three models of the future |last= Gilpin |first= Robert |authorlink= |year= 1975 |publisher= International Organization |location= |isbn= |page= 39 |url= }}</ref>
International business is also a specialist field of academic research. Economic theories of the multinational corporation include [[internalization theory]] and the [[eclectic paradigm]]. The latter is also known as the OLI framework.
The other theoretical dimension of the role of multinational corporations concerns the relationship between the globalization of economic engagement and the culture of national and local responses. This has a history of self-conscious cultural management going back at least to the 1960s. For example:
{{quote|Ernest Dichter, architect, of Exxon's international campaign, writing in the [[Harvard Business Review]] in 1962, was fully aware that the means to overcoming cultural resistance depended on an "understanding" of the countries in which a corporation operated. He observed that companies with "foresight to capitalize on international opportunities" must recognize that "[[cultural anthropology]] will be an important tool for competitive marketing". However, the projected outcome of this was not the assimilation of international firms into national cultures, but the creation of a "world customer". The idea of a global corporate village entailed the management and reconstitution of parochial attachments to one's nation. It involved not a denial of the naturalness of national attachments, but an internationalization of the way a nation defines itself.<ref>{{Cite journal | year= 1983 | last1= James | first1= Paul | authorlink2= Paul James (academic) | title= Australia in the Corporate Image: A New Nationalism | url= https://www.academia.edu/33644385/Australia_in_the_Corporate_Image_A_New_Nationalism_1983_ | journal= Arena | issue= 63 | pages=68}} See also, Richard Barnet and Ronald Muller, Global Reach: The Power of Multinational Corporations, New York, Simon and Schuster, 1974, p. 30. On page 21 Barnet and Muller quote the Chairman of the Unilever Corporation as saying: "The Nation-State will not wither away. A positive role will have to be found for it."</ref>}}
==Transnational corporations== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | header = The United East India Company (VOC) was a pioneering early model of the multinational/transnational corporation at the dawn of modern capitalism.<ref>Steensgaard, Niels (1982). 'The Dutch East India Company as an Institutional Innovation,'; in Maurice Aymard (ed.), ''Dutch Capitalism and World Capitalism / Capitalisme hollandais et capitalisme mondial'' [Studies in Modern Capitalism / Etudes sur le capitalisme moderne], pp. 235–257</ref><ref>Neal, Larry (2005), 'Venture Shares of the Dutch East India Company,'; in Goetzmann & Rouwenhorst (eds.), ''The Origins of Value: The Financial Innovations that Created Modern Capital Markets'', Oxford University Press, 2005, pp. 165–175</ref><ref>Wilson, Eric Michael: ''The Savage Republic: De Indis of Hugo Grotius, Republicanism and Dutch Hegemony within the Early Modern World-System (c.1600–1619)''. (Martinus Nijhoff, 2008, {{ISBN|978-9004167889}}), p. 215–217</ref><ref>Von Nordenflycht, Andrew, 'The Great Expropriation: Interpreting the Innovation of “Permanent Capital” at the Dutch East India Company,'; in ''Origins of Shareholder Advocacy'', edited by Jonathan G.S. Koppell. (Palgrave Macmillan, 2011), pp. 89–98</ref><ref>[[Robert Shiller|Shiller, Robert]]: ''The United East India Company and Amsterdam Stock Exchange'' [00:01:14], in ''Economics 252, Financial Markets: Lecture 4 – Portfolio Diversification and Supporting Financial Institutions''. (Open Yale Courses, 2011)</ref><ref>Jonker, Joost; Gelderblom, Oscar; Dari-Mattiacci, Giuseppe; Perotti, Enrico C. (2013), 'The Emergence of the Corporate Form'. (Amsterdam Center for Law & Economics Working Paper No. 2013-02, 49pp). {{doi|10.2139/ssrn.2223905}}</ref><ref>Jonker, Joost; Gelderblom, Oscar; de Jong, Abe (2013), 'The Formative Years of the Modern Corporation: The Dutch East India Company VOC, 1602–1623,'. The Journal of Economic History 73(4): pp. 1050–1076. {{doi|10.1017/S0022050713000879}}</ref><ref>Funnell, Warwick; Robertson, Jeffrey: ''Accounting by the First Public Company: The Pursuit of Supremacy''. (Routledge, 2014, {{ISBN|0415716179}})</ref><ref>Vasu, Rajkamal (2017), [http://www.kellogg.northwestern.edu/faculty/vasu/A%20Theory%20of%20Permanent%20Capital.pdf?cb=72bd1880 The Transition to Locked-In Capital in the First Corporations: Venture Capital Financing in Early Modern Europe]. ([[Kellogg School of Management]], [[Northwestern University]])</ref> | width = 200 | image1 = Gravure van het Oost Indisch Huis (17e eeuw).jpg | alt1 = | caption1 = 17th-century [[etching]] of the [[Oost-Indisch Huis]] (Dutch for "East India House"), the [[corporate headquarters|global headquarters]] of the [[United East India Company]] (VOC) in Amsterdam. | image2 = Andries Beeckman - The Castle of Batavia.jpg | alt2 = | caption2 = The [[Batavia Castle|Fort Batavia]], seen from West Kali Besar ([[Andries Beeckman]], c. 1656). In [[Batavia, Dutch East Indies|Batavia]] in 1610 the VOC [[Dutch East India Company in Indonesia|established its overseas administrative center]], as the second headquarters, with a [[List of Governors-General of the Dutch East Indies|Governor-General]] in charge, as the Company's ''de facto'' [[chief executive]]. The Company also had [[List of Dutch East India Company trading posts and settlements|important operations]] elsewhere. }} A transnational corporation differs from a traditional multinational corporation in that it does not identify itself with one national home. While traditional multinational corporations are national companies with foreign subsidiaries,<ref name="Drucker">{{cite book |title= The Global Economy and the Nation State |last= Drucker |first= Peter F. |authorlink= |year= 1997 |publisher= Council on Foreign Relations |location= |isbn= |page= 167 |url= http://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:VdRGUsk0-R4J:home.aubg.bg/students/NEN070/pos333/global_economy_nation_state.pdf+%22The+Global+Economy+and+the+Nation+State%22+Peter+F.+Drucket+transnational+corporation+borderless+world&hl=en&gl=uk&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESjWkMhIHM_XJYeV71BNfj8faEl1sg0m6Wmx88iireJl1zTm4CoQtVKcLf12QKc3TvjucPLMHQnjEqnnXWAF7CEjoOJmAx8CsA6aJm3pMPzfg-gVJ0qmHD8jpxaS0bmyKkXT-O09&sig=AHIEtbSZrlgTuJjrY50zW5PnhPkv0LfGVA}}</ref> transnational corporations spread out their operations in many countries to sustain high levels of local responsiveness.<ref name="Case study: The Relationship between the Structure/Strategy of Multinational Corporations and Patterns of Knowledge Sharing within them">{{cite book |title= Case study: The Relationship between the Structure/Strategy of Multinational Corporations and Patterns of Knowledge Sharing within them|year= 2009 |publisher= Oxford University Press|location= |isbn= |page= |pages= |url= http://www.oup.com/uk/orc/bin/9780199534975/01student/cases/case_ch04.pdf}}</ref>
An example of a transnational corporation is [[Nestlé]], who employ senior executives from many countries and tries to make decisions from a global perspective rather than from one centralized headquarters.<ref name="Schermerhorn">{{cite book |title= Exploring Management |last= Schermerhorn |first= John R. |authorlink= |year= 2009 |publisher= John Wiley and Sons |location= |isbn= 0-470-16964-8 |page= 387 |url= https://books.google.com/?id=dkd98RXEzmEC&pg=PA387&lpg=PA387&dq=nestle+transnational+not+multinational#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>
Another example is [[Royal Dutch Shell]], whose headquarters are in [[The Hague]], [[Netherlands]], but whose registered office and main executive body are headquartered in [[London]], [[United Kingdom]].
== Multinational enterprise == "Multinational enterprise" (MNE) is the term used by international economist and similarly defined with the multinational corporation (MNC) as an enterprise that controls and manages production establishments, known as plants located in at least two countries.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/272997700|title=Multinational enterprise and economic analysis|last=E.|first=Caves, Richard|date=2007|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=|isbn=9780521677530|location=|pages=1|oclc=272997700}}</ref> The multinational enterprise (MNE) will engage in [[Foreign direct investment|foreign direct investment (FDI)]] as the firm makes direct investments in host country plants for equity ownership and managerial control to avoid some [[transaction cost]]s.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/272997700|title=Multinational enterprise and economic analysis|last=E.|first=Caves, Richard|date=2007|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=|isbn=9780521677530|location=|pages=69|oclc=272997700}}</ref>
==Colonialism== {{See also|Charter company|Neocolonialism}} The history of multinational corporations is closely intertwined with the [[history of colonialism]], the first multinational corporations being founded to undertake colonial expeditions at the behest of their European monarchical patrons.<ref>Jeffrey, Alex, and Joe Painter. "Imperialism and Post colonialism." Political Geography: An Introduction to Space and Power. London: SAGE, 2009. 174-75. Print.</ref> Prior to the era of [[New Imperialism]], a majority European colonies not held by the Spanish and Portuguese crowns were administered by chartered multinational corporations.<ref>Robins, Nick. "This Imperious Company." The Corporation That Changed the World How the East India Company Shaped the Modern Multinational. London: Pluto, 2006. 24-25. Print.</ref> Examples of such corporations include the [[British East India Company]],<ref>Robins, Nick. The Corporation That Changed the World How the East India Company Shaped the Modern Multinational. London: Pluto, 2006. Print.</ref> the [[Swedish Africa Company]], and the [[Hudson's Bay Company]].<ref>Royle, Stephen A. Company, Crown and Colony: The Hudson's Bay Company and Territorial Endeavor in Western Canada. London: I.B. Tauris, 2011. Print.</ref> These early corporations facilitated [[colonialism]] by engaging in [[international trade]] and exploration, and creating colonial [[trading posts]].<ref name="Micklethwait, John 2003">Micklethwait, John, and Adrian Wooldridge. 2003. The company: A short history of a revolutionary idea. New York: Modern Library.</ref> Many of these corporations, such as the [[South Australia Company]] and the [[Virginia Company]], played a direct role in formal [[colonization]] by creating and maintaining settler [[colonies]].<ref name="Micklethwait, John 2003"/> Without exception these early corporations created differential economic outcomes between their home country and their colonies via a process of [[exploitation of labour|exploiting]] colonial resources and labour, and investing the resultant [[profit (accounting)|profits]] and net gain in the home country.<ref>Howe, Stephen. "Empire by Sea." Empire: A Very Short Introduction. Oxford: Oxford UP, 2002. 77-80. Print.</ref> The end result of this process was the enrichment of the colonizer and the impoverishment of the colonized.<ref name="uib.cat">{{cite journal|last=Angeles|first=Luis|title=Income Inequality and Colonialism|publisher=European Economic Review 51.5 (2007): 1155-176|url=http://www.uib.cat/congres/ecopub/ecineq/papers/011Angeles.pdf|format=PDF|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150207185212/http://www.uib.cat/congres/ecopub/ecineq/papers/011Angeles.pdf|archivedate=2015-02-07|df=}}</ref> Some multinational corporations, such as the [[Royal African Company]], were also responsible for the logistical component of the [[Atlantic slave trade]],<ref>Howe, Stephen. "Empire by Sea." Empire: A Very Short Introduction. Oxford: Oxford UP, 2002. 67. Print.</ref> maintaining the ships and ports required for this vast enterprise. During the 19th century, formal corporate rule over colonial holdings largely gave way to state-controlled colonies,<ref name="Jeffrey, Alex 2009">Jeffrey, Alex, and Joe Painter. "Imperialism and Postcolonialism." Political Geography: An Introduction to Space and Power. London: SAGE, 2009. 175. Print.</ref><ref>Robins, Nick. The Corporation That Changed the World How the East India Company Shaped the Modern Multinational. London: Pluto, 2006. 145. Print.</ref> however corporate control over colonial economic affairs persisted in a majority of colonies.<ref name="Micklethwait, John 2003"/><ref name="Jeffrey, Alex 2009"/>
During the process of [[decolonization]], the European colonial [[charter companies]] were disbanded,<ref name="Micklethwait, John 2003"/> with the final colonial corporation, the [[Mozambique Company]], dissolving in 1972. However the economic impact of corporate colonial exploitation has proved to be lasting and far reaching,<ref>Howe, Stephen. "Empire by Sea." Empire: A Very Short Introduction. Oxford: Oxford UP, 2002. 78-83. Print.</ref> with some commentators asserting that this impact is among the chief causes of contemporary global [[income inequality]].<ref name="uib.cat"/>
Contemporary critics of multinational corporations have charged that some present day multinational corporations follow the pattern of exploitation and differential wealth distribution established by the now defunct colonial charter corporations, particularly with regards to corporations based in the developed world that operate resource extraction enterprises in the developing world,<ref>Bakan, Joel. The Corporation: The Pathological Pursuit of Profit and Power. New York: Free, 2004. Print.</ref> such as [[Royal Dutch Shell]], and [[Barrick Gold]]. Some of these critics argue that the operations of multinational corporations in the developing world take place within the broader context of [[neocolonialism]].<ref>Azikiwe, Abayomi. "Burkina Faso: Masses Rise Up Against Neo-Colonial Rule." Global Research. Centre for Research on Globalization, 04 Nov. 2014. Web. 07 Feb. 2015.</ref>
However, multinational corporations from emerging markets are playing an ever-greater role, increasingly impacting the global economy.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.dandc.eu/en/briefings/multinational-corporations-emerging-markets-are-forces-be-reckoned-long-term |title= Dossier about emerging-market multinationals |publisher= D+C, development and cooperation |date= December 2015 |accessdate= 21 December 2015}}</ref>
==Criticism== {{Main|Anti-globalization movement|Anti-corporate activism}} Anti-corporate advocates criticize multinational corporations for being without a basis in a national [[ethos]], being ultimately without a specific nationhood, and that this lack of an ethos appears in their ways of operating as they enter into contracts with countries that have low [[human rights]] or [[environmental law|environmental standards]].<ref>Marc 'Globalization, Power, and Survival: an Anthropological Perspective', pg 484–486. ''Anthropological Quarterly'' Vol.79, No. 3. Institute for Ethnographic Research, 2006</ref> In the world economy facilitated by multinational corporations, capital will increasingly be able to play workers, communities, and nations off against one another as they demand tax, regulation and wage concessions while threatening to move. In other words, increased mobility of multinational corporations benefit capital while workers and communities lose. Some negative outcomes generated by multinational corporations include increased [[social inequality|inequality]], [[unemployment]], and [[wage stagnation]].<ref name="Crotty">{{cite book |title= Multinational corps in neo-liberal regime |last= Crotty |first= Epstein & Kelly |year= 1998 |publisher= Cambridge University Press |location= |isbn= |page= 2 |url= }}</ref>
The aggressive use of [[tax avoidance]] schemes, and [[multinational tax haven]]s, allows multinational corporations to gain competitive advantages over [[small and medium-sized enterprises]].<ref>Library of the European Parliament [http://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/bibliotheque/briefing/2013/130574/LDM_BRI%282013%29130574_REV1_EN.pdf Corporate tax avoidance by multinational firms]</ref> Organizations such as the [[Tax Justice Network]] criticize governments for allowing multinational organizations to escape tax, particularly by using [[base erosion and profit shifting]] (BEPS) tax tools, since less money can be spent for public services.<ref>Tax Justice Network, [http://www.taxjustice.net/topics/corporate-tax/taxing-corporations/ Taxing corporations]</ref>

revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Labour relations to [[:Category:Labor relations]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
{{Infobox holiday |type=secular |holiday_name=National Day of Mourning |duration= 1 day |scheduling = 28th day of April |frequency=annual |observedby=Canada |image = |caption= |date=28th day of April |longtype= |week_ordinal= |weekday= |month=April |celebrations=flag at half-mast, [[Moment of silence]], lighting candles, donning ribbons and black armbands |relatedto=[[Labor Day]]; [[Workers' Memorial Day]] }} The '''National Day of Mourning''', or '''Workers’ Mourning Day''' is observed in [[Canada]] on 28 April. It commemorates workers who have been killed, injured or suffered illness due to workplace related hazards and occupational exposures.
Workers' Memorial Day was started when two labour activists, Colin Lambert and Dr. Ray Sentes, were driving in early April 1983 to a union meeting, and were stopped by a funeral procession for a firefighter that had been killed in the line of duty<ref>{{Citation|last=BC Labour Heritage Centre|title=Day of Mourning The Untold Story (2017)|date=2017-04-20|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hP0JvrXjmgo&feature=youtu.be|accessdate=2018-05-09}}</ref>. They worried that other workers who died because of work did not receive similar honours, and recalled how members of the United Steelworkers in Elliott Lake held each year a "Workers' Remembrance Day" for uranium miners who had succumbed to exposures. Lambert and Sentes sought endorsements from union officials for the idea to hold a national day of mourning, and the Canadian Union of Public Employees (CUPE) passed a resolution to that effect at its annual convention in 1983, and the Canadian Labour Congress followed suit at its annual convention the following year. The AFL-CIO declared a day of mourning in 1989 and a "workers' Memorial Day" is observed in over 100 countries.
In December 1990, this day became a national observance in Canada with the passing of the Workers Mourning Day Act, so that on April 28, 1991, it was officially the National Day of Mourning for persons killed or injured in the workplace; making April 28, an official Workers’ Mourning Day.<ref name="Manchester">[[Greater Manchester Hazards Centre]] Fact Sheet 28 April 2006 (GMHC is part of the [[Hazards Campaign]] recognised and affiliated to the UK [[Trades Union Congress]]) Author Hilda Palmer, (no ISBN); available at {{cite web |url=http://www.gmhazards.org.uk/WMDLft06.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-03-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060518055811/http://www.gmhazards.org.uk/WMDLft06.pdf |archivedate=2006-05-18 |df= }} Also '''Safety Express' March/ April 2006 Page 5'' 'April 28th is...Workers' Memorial Day' (no ISBN); published by The [[Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents]] ([[ROSPA]]) UK [[registered charity]] No. 207823</ref><ref name="ohs">TUC Certificate in Occupational Health & Safety course notes 2004/5 Section C page 69 (no ISBN); more info available at {{cite web |url=http://www.tuc.org.uk/h_and_s/index.cfm?mins=293 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-03-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100217003146/http://www.tuc.org.uk/h_and_s/index.cfm?mins=293 |archivedate=2010-02-17 |df= }}</ref>
Injuries and deaths in the workplace continue to be a matter of important concern across Canada. Many Canadians members work hard each day in an effort to minimize accidents and incidents. Risk is an inherent element of many jobs, and this is why safety should be one of the core values in any workplace. Since its inception, the observance has spread to over 80 countries around the world, but is known is most other countries as the [[Workers' Memorial Day]]. The date 28 April was picked because on that day in 1914, the [http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/workers-compensation/ Workers Compensation Act] received its third reading. In 2001 the [[International Labour Organization]] first observed World Day for Safety and Health at Work on this day. Commemorating those who have been hurt or killed in the workplace shows respect for the fallen, while serving as a reminder of the importance of occupational health and safety.
The Canadian flag is flown at half-mast from sunrise to sunset on all federal government buildings, including on Parliament Hill. Workers and employees observe this day in various ways including lighting candles, donning ribbons and black armbands, and observing a moment of silence at 1100 hrs. The purpose of Day of Mourning is twofold- to remember and honour those lives lost or injured and to renew the commitment to improving health and safety in the workplace - to prevent further deaths, injuries and diseases from work.
==Young Workers== Young workers aged from 15-24 are more likely than any other group to be injured on the job, in fact 1/3 of all injuries occur in this age group, and males are twice as likely to be injured as female workers.<ref name="YoungStats">[[WorkSafeBC]] Young Workers Rights and Facts, http://www.labourheritagecentre.ca/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/6-FactSheet-Bugged-Revision-3-.pdf.</ref> The highest rate of injury happens in construction and hospitality industries. These rates have led to specific laws in many provinces that provide for additional and special training for young and new workers.<ref name="Young">[[WorkSafeBC]] Young Workers Resource and Fact Page, http://www2.worksafebc.com/Topics/YoungWorker/Home.asp.</ref> Due to these statistics, there has been renewed push to use this holiday to educate young workers of their rights in schools.<ref name="Schools">Day of Mourning, BC Schools Project, http://www.labourheritagecentre.ca/domschoolsproject/</ref>
==Canadian monuments== Major monuments in Canada have been erected and dedicated to workers whose lives have been who have been killed and injured on the job.<ref>{{ccohs|date=2015 04 27|url=http://www.ccohs.ca/events/mourning/ |title=Monuments Canada }}.</ref>
* The Canadian Young Workers Memorial Quilt -The LifeQuilt with individual, personalized quilted blocks commemorated 100 young workers is a memorial dedicated to the thousands of young women and men between the ages of 14 and 24 killed on the job.<ref>{{date=2015 04 27|url=http://lifequilt.ca/ |title=Young Workers Memorial Life Quilt }}.</ref> * [[Canadian Labour Congress]] Monument, [[Vincent Massey Park]], [[Ottawa|Ottawa, Ontario]], Canada - This monument was dedicated on April 28, 1987, one year after the Canadian Labour Congress had officially established April 28 as the Day of Mourning to workers killed and injured on the job.<ref>{{date=2015 04 27|url=http://www.ccohs.ca/events/mourning/labourcongress.html|title="Dead But Not Forgotten–Monuments to Workers" a book by Ed Thomas }}.</ref> * Falconbridge Mural, [[Sudbury, Ontario]], Canada * Miner's Memorial [[Kirkland Lake, Ontario]] Canada * [[Rideau Canal]] Fabric Mural Memorial, [[Kingston, Ontario]], Canada * Fire Fighter's Monument, [[Saskatoon, Saskatchewan]], Canada * "Breaking Ground" Hoggs Hollow Memorial, [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada * 'Their Light Shall Always Shine' Memorial Park, New Glasgow, Nova Scotia is a park and memorial dedicated to the 26 miners who lost their lives in a horrific mining explosion on May 9, 1992. http://ns1763.ca/pictouco/westraymem.html * "Broken Families Obelisk" Grant Notley Park, [[Edmonton]], [[Alberta]], Canada * Welland Canal Fallen Workers Memorial, [[St. Catharines]], [[Ontario]], Canada
The [http://www.labourheritagecentre.ca/ BC Labour Heritage Centre] maintains an [http://www.labourheritagecentre.ca/workermemorialmap/ interactive map] recording all monuments and plaques dedicated to working class people in British Columbia, over fifty sites of which are Day of Mourning specific.
==International monuments== Monuments around the world have been erected and dedicated to workers whose lives have been who have been killed and injured on the job.<ref>{{ccohs|date=2015 04 27|url=http://www.ccohs.ca/events/mourning/ |title=Monuments International }}.</ref> * [[Hoover Dam]] Monument, [[Boulder City, Nevada]], USA * Airplane and Fishermen Monument, [[Hedinsfjordur, Iceland]] * Workers Memorial Day Stained Glass Window, [[Birmingham, England]] * Deceased Workers Memorial Forest [Adelaide South Australia} *National Deceased Workers Memorial (Workers Glade) [Canberra Australia]
==See also== *[[Labor Day]] *[[Workers' Memorial Day]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox company |name = OTP Bank Nyrt. |logo = Otp bank Logo.svg |logo_size = 150px |type = [[Public company|Public]] |traded_as = {{Budapest Stock Exchange|OTP|isin=HU0000061726}}
{{Euronext|OTP}}
[[BUX|BUX Component]]
[[CETOP20|CETOP20 Component]] |industry = [[Banking]], [[Financial services]] |location_city = [[Budapest]] |location_country = [[Hungary]] |foundation = 1949 |area_served = [[Central and Eastern Europe]] |key_people = [[Sándor Csányi (banker)|Sándor Csányi]]
(Chairman & CEO) |products = [[Retail banking|Consumer banking]], [[Commercial bank|corporate banking]], [[credit card]]s, [[Financial services|finance and insurance]], [[foreign currency exchange]], [[investment banking]], [[mortgage loan]]s, [[private banking]], [[private equity]], [[wealth management]] |revenue = {{Increase}} [[Hungarian Forint|HUF]] 645.465 billion (2012){{cite web|url=https://www.otpbank.hu/static/portal/sw/file/130426_IFRS_konsz_e.pdf|format=PDF|title=Annual Report 2012|accessdate=30 May 2013|publisher=OTP|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150610215132/https://www.otpbank.hu/static/portal/sw/file/130426_IFRS_konsz_e.pdf|archivedate=10 June 2015|df=}} |operating_income = {{Increase}} HUF 145.674 billion (2012) |net_income = {{Increase}} HUF 122.586 billion (2012) |assets = {{Decrease}} HUF 10133.4 billion (2012) |equity = {{Increase}} HUF 1514.55 billion (2012) |num_employees = 36,366 (2012) |subsid = [[OTP banka Srbija]], [[DSK Bank]], [[Crnogorska komercijalna banka|Crnogorska banka]], ''see full list in OTP Group section'' |homepage = {{URL|https://www.otpbank.hu/portal/en/home|''otpbank.com}} }} '''OTP Bank Group''' is one of the largest independent financial services providers in [[Central and Eastern Europe]] with full range of banking services for private individuals and corporate clients. OTP Group comprise large subsidiaries, granting services in the field of insurance, real estate, factoring, leasing and asset management, investment and pension funds. The bank is serving clients in 9 countries, namely [[Hungary]], [[Slovakia]], [[Bulgaria]], [[Serbia]], [[Romania]], [[Croatia]], [[Ukraine]], [[Montenegro]] and [[Russia]]. Nowadays OTP Groups' more than 36,000 employees are serving 13 million clients in over 1,500 branches and through electronic channels on all the markets of the bank.{{cite web|url=https://www.otpbank.hu/portal/en/OTPGroup|title=OTP Bank - Magánszemélyek|author=|date=|website=www.otpbank.hu|accessdate=26 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140810050000/https://www.otpbank.hu/portal/en/OTPGroup|archivedate=10 August 2014|df=}} OTP is still the largest [[commercial bank]] in [[Hungary]] with over 25% market share.{{cite web|url=https://www.otpbank.hu/portal/en/OTPGroup/OTPBank|title=OTP Bank - Magánszemélyek|author=|date=|website=www.otpbank.hu|accessdate=26 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203002731/https://www.otpbank.hu/portal/en/OTPGroup/OTPBank|archivedate=3 December 2013|df=}} OTP Group started its activity in 1949 when OTP Bank was founded as a state savings and commercial bank. '''OTP''' stands for '''O'''rszágos '''T'''akarék '''P'''énztár (National Savings Bank) which indicates the origin purpose of establishment of the bank. The bank went public in 1995, and the share of the state in the bank capital decreased to one preferential gold share, which also eliminated shortly thereafter. Currently most of the banks' shares are owned by private and institutional investors, which ensures stable ownership structure of the company. OTP has a high [[free float]] shareholder structure, the free float ratio reaches the 68,61%. The rest is held by one of the [[Forbes]] billionaire [[Megdet Rahimkulov]] in 8,88%, Hungarian [[MOL Group]] in 8,57%, French [[Groupama]] in 8,30% and American [[Lazard]] in 5,64%.{{cite web |url=http://client.bse.hu/menun_kivuli/portlets/companyprofile?security=528 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-06-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130130164325/http://client.bse.hu/menun_kivuli/portlets/companyprofile?security=528 |archivedate=2013-01-30 |df= }} ==History== The predecessor of OTP Bank, called the National Savings Bank (OTP Bank) was established in 1949 as a nationwide, state-owned, banking entity providing retail deposits and loans. In the ensuing years, its activities and the scope of its authority gradually widened. First, it was authorised to enter into real estate transactions. Later, its role was extended to provide domestic foreign currency accounts and foreign exchange services; there was a subsequent diversification into providing banking services for Hungarian municipalities. Since 1989, the bank has operated as a multi-functional commercial bank. In addition to continuing its previous retail and municipal activities, the bank has been authorised to solicit corporate loan accounts and deposits, and to provide commercial loans and banking services for correspondent banking and export-import transactions. In 1990, the National Savings Bank became a public company with a share capital of HUF 23 billion. Its name was changed to the National Savings and Commercial Bank. Subsequently, non-banking activities were separated from the bank, along with their supporting organisational units. The state lottery was reorganised into a separate state-owned company and OTP Real Estate was established as a subsidiary of the bank. [[Image:Otp bank Logo old.svg|thumb|150px|left|OTP Bank logo used between 1991 and 2007]] OTP Bank's privatisation began in 1995. As a result of 3 public offers along with the introduction of the bank's shares into the Budapest Stock Exchange the state's ownership in the bank decreased to a single voting preference (golden) share. Currently the bank is characterized by dispersed ownership of mostly private and institutional (financial) investors. After the realisation of its own privatisation process, OTP Bank started its international expansion targeting countries in CEE{{clarify|date=December 2016}} region. OTP Bank has completed several acquisitions in the past years. Besides Hungary, OTP Group currently operates in 8 countries of the region via its subsidiaries: in Bulgaria ([[DSK Bank]]), in Croatia (OTP banka Hrvatska), in Romania (OTP Bank Romania), in Serbia ([[OTP banka Srbija]]), in Slovakia (OTP Banka Slovensko), in Ukraine (OTP Bank JSC), in Montenegro (Crnogorska komercijalna banka) and in Russia (OAO OTP Bank). 2008 was milestone in OTP Bank history since it was the first time to sell one of its subsidiaries. The French Groupama S.A. acquired its insurance business line, and part of the transaction they resolved to collaborate in strategic points and crossell their financial and insurance products. Groupama S.A. has acquired 8% of shares of OTP Group. In April 2014, it was announced that OTP Bank was close to a deal to acquire the Hungarian [[MKB Bank]] from German firm [[BayernLB]].{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/04/08/us-otp-bk-mkb-bank-idUSBREA370HK20140408| title=Hungary's biggest bank OTP nearing deal to buy MKB| publisher=Reuters| date=8 April 2014| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924195628/http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/04/08/us-otp-bk-mkb-bank-idUSBREA370HK20140408 | archivedate=24 September 2015| df=}} French [[AXA Bank Europe]] announced in February 2016 it has entered into an agreement with OTP Bank to sell its Hungarian banking operations, which is considered as medium-sized bank in Hungary.{{cite news| url=http://www.intellinews.com/otp-agrees-to-buy-axa-s-hungarian-banking-unit-89925/?source=bne-banker| title=OTP agrees to buy Axa's Hungarian banking unit| publisher=IntelliNews| date=2016| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160404103744/http://www.intellinews.com/otp-agrees-to-buy-axa-s-hungarian-banking-unit-89925/?source=bne-banker| archivedate=2016-04-04| df=}} == OTP Group == [[File:Countries with OTP Bank.png|thumb|300px|right|Map with countries that have branch of OTP bank marked in green.]] The Bank hosts an international organisation called the OTP group. The several parts of the group work in different areas of business. {| class="wikitable sortable" |- | OTP Bank Nyrt. || Universal Bank |- | Merkantil Bank Ltd. || Personal Loans |- | Merkantil Car Ltd. || Auto Leasing |- | Merkantil Lease Ltd. || Leasing |- | OTP Building Society Ltd. || Savings Bank |- | OTP Mortgage Bank Ltd. || Mortgage Bank |- | [[DSK Bank]] (Банка ДСК) || Universal Bank ([[Bulgaria]]) |- | OTP Banka Slovensko, a.s. || Universal Bank ([[Slovakia]]) |- | OTP Bank Romania SA || Commercial Bank ([[Romania]]) |- | OTP banka Hrvatska d.d. || Commercial Bank ([[Croatia]]) |- |[[Splitska banka|Splitska banka d.d.]] |Commercial Bank ([[Croatia]]) |- |[[OTP banka Srbija|OTP banka Srbija a.d. Novi Sad]] |Commercial Bank ([[Serbia]]) |- |Crnogorska komercijalna banka a.d. |Commercial Bank ([[Montenegro]]) |- | OTP Capital || Asset Management Company ([[Ukraine]]) |- | OTP Fund Management Ltd. || Investment Fund |- | OTP Real Estate Fund Management Ltd. || Investment Fund |- | Hungarian International Finance Ltd. || International Financing |- | OTP Real Estate Ltd. || Construction and sale of properties |- | OTP Lakáslízing || Mortgage |- | OTP Factoring Ltd. || Factoring, forfeiting |- | OTP Factoring Trustee Ltd. || Evaluation and sale of properties |- | OTP Pension || Non-government Pension Fund ([[Ukraine]]) |- | OTP Health Fund || Health Fund |- | OTP Travel Ltd. || Travel Agency |- | OTP Életjáradék Zrt. || Pension Fund |} == Buildings ==

{{Infobox military person |name = Olga E. Custodio |birth_date = 1953 |birth_place = [[San Juan, Puerto Rico]] |death_date = |death_place = |image =Lt. Olga Custodio.jpg |image_size=150 |caption = Then Lieutenant Custodio climbing down from the cockpit of a T-38 |nickname = |allegiance = {{flagicon|United States}} [[United States|United States of America]] |serviceyears = 1980–2003 |rank =[[File:US-O5 insignia.svg|25px]] Lieutenant Colonel |branch = [[Image:Seal of the US Air Force.svg|25px]] [[United States Air Force]]
[[File:Air Force Reserve Command.png|25x25px]] [[Air Force Reserve Command|Air Force Reserve]] |commands = |unit = |battles = |awards = |laterwork = American Airlines Pilot - one of the first Hispanic women to become a commercial airline captain }} Lieutenant Colonel '''Olga E. Custodio''' '''Custodio''' is the surname by marriage. (born 1953) is a former [[United States Air Force]] officer who became the first female [[Hispanic]] U.S. military pilot. She was the first Hispanic woman to complete U.S. Air Force military pilot training. Upon retiring from the military, she became one of the first female Hispanic commercial airline captains. ==Early years== Custodio was born in [[San Juan, Puerto Rico]]. Her father, a sergeant in the [[United States Army]], was often stationed in various countries where the [[United States]] has its military installations. Custodio and the rest of the family would accompany him on his overseas assignments. Custodio began her primary education in [[Taiwan]]. She also attended schools in [[New Jersey]], [[Iran]] and [[Paraguay]]. The family returned to Puerto Rico when she was 15 years old. She graduated high school at age 16, and was immediately accepted into the [[University of Puerto Rico]]. Custodio's father, and all the traveling she did at a young age, were key factors in her choice of career - she decided to join the military. While in college she attempted to join the university’s ROTC ([[Reserve Officer Training Corps]]), but at the time only men were admitted into the program. ==Military career== [[File:T-38 560FTS RandolphAFB 2001.jpeg|300px|thumb| A USAF T-38A Talon from [[560th Flying Training Squadron]], Randolph Air Force Base Texas]] Custodio earned a Bachelor of Arts degree from the University of Puerto Rico and worked for various industries before landing a job in the accounting department of [[Prinair]] (Puerto Rico International Airlines). There she met Edwin Custodio, with whom she would eventually have two children. She later worked for the [[US Department of Defense]] (DoD) in [[Panama]]. With the support of her husband, she presented herself before Headquarters, Air Force Military Personnel Center (AFMPC) to apply for the United States Air Force [[Officers Candidate School|Officer Training School]]. Upon admission, Custodio was accepted as a pilot candidate to become a United States Air Force pilot. She entered the Flight Screening Pilot Officer Training School in January 1980. After successful completion of Flight Screening she entered Officer Training School and was commissioned a [[Second Lieutenant]]. She qualified for Undergraduate Pilot Training (UPT) at [[Laughlin Air Force Base]] in [[Texas]] and graduated the following year, thus becoming the first Latina to complete the U.S. Air Force military pilot training. Her first military assignment was that of instructor pilot at Laughlin AFB. She was the first female to become a [[Northrop T-38 Talon]] (T-38) UPT flight instructor at that base. The T-38 Talon is the Air Force’s two-seat, supersonic jet trainer. On one occasion a bird struck the engine of her plane in bad weather while she was in flight. She was able to overcome the emergency and safely land her plane. Because of this she was recognized by the Air Force, and awarded the HQ AETC Aviation Safety Award for superior airmanship. Custodio was later assigned to [[Randolph Air Force Base]] where she was also the first female T-38 Instructor Pilot. During her career she also served as Pilot Instructor Training; T-41 Flight Screening - Operations Officer and Check Pilot. Custodio retired from the Air Force with the rank of lieutenant colonel in October 2003, after serving in the military for 23 years and 10 months. Her last assignment as an Air Force Reserve officer was that of accountability and readiness the Directorate of Personnel, HQ USAF. ==Commercial airline captain== [[File:aa b767-300er n363aa arp.jpg|thumb|[[Boeing 767|Boeing 767–300ER]], one of the many types of American Airline aircraft flown by Custodio]] In June 1988, while she was serving in the US Air Force Reserve, she was hired by [[American Airlines]] as a commercial pilot. Custodio became one of the first [[Latina]] commercial airline captains.[https://books.google.com/books?id=JdonK_e59VcC&pg=PA13&lpg=PA13&dq=linda+pauwels&source=bl&ots=wzfNu2WUXm&sig=iSpN505Uwnj_LSjeIioavQtqfLc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi2lc-88Z7aAhVEw4MKHZSkAB04ChDoAQgtMAE#v=onepage&q=linda%20pauwels&f=false "Reaching Your Potential: Personal and Professional Development", Linda Pauwels as First Hispanic Woman to captain a jet for American Airlines, Retrieved 2018-08-07] During her years with American, she flew various types of aircraft. She piloted the [[Boeing 727]], [[Fokker 100]], [[Boeing 757]] and [[Boeing 767]] to various countries in [[Europe]], the [[Caribbean]], [[Central America]] and [[South America]]. She also flew to [[Mexico]], [[Canada]] and to various cities in the United States. Custodio retired from American Airlines in February 2008, with over 11,000 flight hours. ==Later years== Custodio retired from the military after 24 years of service and lives in [[San Antonio, Texas]], with her husband. There she founded "Dragonfly Productions LLC," a production company that creates personal film documentaries. In 1992, she founded the ''Ballet Folklorico Borikèn,'' the Puerto Rican folk ballet. Custodio is a Trustee of the Order of Daedalians Foundation, a Board Member and Treasurer for the Women in Aviation Alamo City Chapter and Board Member for the Dee Howard Foundation. Custodio also serves as vice president of the Hispanic Association of Aviation and Aerospace Professionals (HAAAP). These organizations inspire young students in the San Antonio and surrounding areas to seek civilian and military aviation careers. They hosts students to tour various airplanes and control towers and also speak to students in all grades to present career opportunities in aviation and aerospace. ==Memberships== Among the many associations in which Custodio is a member are the following: *Charter member of the Women Military Aviators Association *The Women in Aviation, International, Inc. *Order of Daedalians *The Allied Pilots Association. ==Education and professional certificates== Besides the Bachelor of Arts degree which she earned in the University of Puerto Rico, Custodio has also earned the following: *Air Transport Pilot certificate with single and multiengine land and instrument ratings. *Flight Engineer Certificate – Turbojet Powered rating *Radiotelephone Operator permit *FAA Medical Certificate ==Recognitions== Custodio was recognized twice by the [[Senate of Puerto Rico]]. In 2001, she was recognized by [[Elizabeth Arden]]/Revista Imagen of Puerto Rico as one of the recipient of ''La Belleza Inteligente 2001'' award.In 2017, Custodio was inducted into the San Antonio Aviation and Aerospace Hall of Fame for being the first Hispanic Female Military pilot in the United States Air Force.[http://www.portsanantonio.us/Webpages.asp?wpid=512 San Antonio Aviation and Aerospace Hall of Fame] ==See also== {{Portal|Puerto Rico|United States Air Force}} *[[List of Puerto Ricans]] *[[Puerto Rican women in the military]] *[[List of Puerto Rican military personnel]] *[[Military history of Puerto Rico]] *[[Hispanics in the United States Air Force]] *[[History of women in Puerto Rico]] {{clear}} ==Notes== ==References== {{Reflist|refs= {{cite news |url=http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/community/2012/05/28/our-american-dream-meet-first-latina-us-military-pilot/?test=latestnews |title=Our American Dream: Meet the First Latina US Military Pilot|first=Graciela |last=Tiscareño-Sato |date=May 28, 2012 |work=Fox News Latino |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160416113828/http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/community/2012/05/28/our-american-dream-meet-first-latina-us-military-pilot/?test=latestnews |archivedate=2016-04-16 }} {{cite web |url=http://militarycityusaradio.com/?p=329 |title=Olga E. Custodio|date=March 5, 2011 |publisher=MilitaryCityUSARadio.com |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110319121210/http://militarycityusaradio.com/?p=329 |archivedate=2011-03-19 }} {{cite news|accessdate=2018-04-02 |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2151283/Olga-Custodio-Meet-Latina-US-military-pilot.html?ito=feeds-newsxml |title='When I was told to list the three jobs I wanted, I said: "Pilot, pilot or pilot"': Meet the first Latina to fly planes for the US military |author=''Daily Mail'' Reporter |work=The Daily Mail |date=28 May 2012 }} }} ==Further reading== * {{cite news|accessdate=2018-04-02 |title=First Air Force Latina pilot: Lt. Col. Olga E. Fighting to Defend a Nation Not Completely Their Own|first=Greg |last=Boudonck|date=March 14, 2014|ISBN=1497421837}} *{{cite web|accessdate=2018-04-02 |title=National Hispanic Heritage Month: Olga E. Use image_upright. --> | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | pronunciation = | birth_name = | birth_date = October 17, 1989 | birth_place = [[Reus]], [[Catalonia]], | baptised = <!-- will not display if birth_date is entered --> | disappeared_date = <!-- {{disappeared date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (disappeared date then birth date) --> | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | burial_place = <!-- may be used instead of resting_place and resting_place_coordinates (displays "Burial place" as label) --> | burial_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | monuments = | residence = | nationality = [[Spain|Spanish]] | other_names = | citizenship = [[Spain]] | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = Spanish entrepreneur, LGBT activist and Tourism expert. | years_active = | era = | employer = | organization = | agent = <!-- Discouraged in most cases, specifically when promotional, and requiring a reliable source --> | known_for = LGBT activism and co-founder of ''Moovz'', an LGBT social network | notable_works = <!-- produces label "Notable work"; may be overridden by |credits=, which produces label "Notable credit(s)"; or by |works=, which produces label "Works" --> | style = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = <!-- Net worth should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | height = <!-- "X cm", "X m" or "X ft Y in" plus optional reference (conversions are automatic) --> | weight = <!-- "X kg", "X lb" or "X st Y lb" plus optional reference (conversions are automatic) --> | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | criminal_charge = <!-- Criminality parameters should be supported with citations from reliable sources --> | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = <!-- Use article title or common name --> | partner = <!-- (unmarried long-term partner) --> | children = | parents = <!-- overrides mother and father parameters --> | mother = <!-- may be used (optionally with father parameter) in place of parents parameter (displays "Parent(s)" as label) --> | father = <!-- may be used (optionally with mother parameter) in place of parents parameter (displays "Parent(s)" as label) --> | relatives = | family = | callsign = | awards = | website = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | footnotes = }}
'''Oriol Pamies''' (born October 17, 1989) is a [[Spain|Spanish]] entrepreneur, [[LGBT]] activist and tourism expert.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =El mercado LGBT gasta US$800 mil millones al año en EE.UU| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''elcomercio.pe''| date = | url =https://elcomercio.pe/economia/negocios/mercado-lgbt-gasta-us-800-mil-millones-ano-ee-uu-210116 | accessdate =21 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =LGBT Community Thanks Pope Francis for Calling them 'Gifted', Celebrates Success of #ComingOut Campaign | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''ibtimes.co.in''| date = | url =http://www.ibtimes.co.in/lgbt-community-thanks-pope-francis-calling-them-gifted-celebrates-success-comingout-campaign-611604 | accessdate =21 December 2017}}</ref> He is a co-founder of ''Moovz'', an LGBT social network.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =LGBTQ Social Influencers: Public Figures With Personal Messages | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''adweek.com''| date =11 December 2015 | url =http://www.adweek.com/digital/lgbtq-social-influencers/ | accessdate =21 December 2017}}</ref>
==Early life== Pamies was born in [[Reus]], [[Catalonia]]. He lived there with his family until he moved to [[Barcelona]] to study Advertising and PR in 2008. He later dropped out of college to start pursuing his entrepreneurial career.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Oriol Pamies "Hay muchos elementos de Barcelona que Tel Aviv también tiene" | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''elblogdelajamua.blogspot.com''| date = | url =http://elblogdelajamua.blogspot.com/2016/01/oriol-pamies-hay-muchos-elementos-de.html | accessdate =21 December 2017}}</ref>
In 2012, following an invitation from [[Idan Matalon]], Pamies travelled to [[Israel]] to explore new business opportunities.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Oriol Pamies, VP Business Development for MOOVZ Discusses Advertising Trends in the LGBT Community| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''laguestlist.com''| date =20 January 2016 | url =https://laguestlist.com/moovz-post/ | accessdate =21 December 2017}}</ref>
==Career== ===Moovz and LGBT activism=== Pamies' visit to Israel led him to join the Israeli start-up Interacting Technology as their VP Business Development becoming one of the founders of ''Moovz'', an LGBT social network.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =NOTICIASOriol Pamies: El mercado LGBT gasta US$800 mil millones al año en EE.UU| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''life.lgbt''| date =27 May 2016 | url =http://life.lgbt/oriol-pamies-mercado-lgbt-gasta-us800-mil-millones-al-ano-ee-uu/ | accessdate =21 December 2017}}</ref> While in Israel he became an active member of the local LGBT and tech community.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Moovz: el hijo gay de Facebook e Instagram ya está en Colombia| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''shock.co''| date = | url =https://www.shock.co/noticias/articulos/el-hijo-gay-de-facebook-e-instagram-ya-esta-en-colombia-84638 | accessdate =21 December 2017}}</ref> According to [[HuffPost|Huffington Post]], in 2015, during the [[National Coming Out Day]], Pamies produced a campaign for Moovz encouraging individuals to come out of the closet and share their stories through the hashtag "#ComingOut."<ref>{{cite news | last =James | first =Nichols | title =Moovz Social Networking App Celebrates #ComingOut| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''huffingtonpost.com''| date = | url =https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/10/11/moovz-social-netwokring-a_n_5968090.html | accessdate =21 December 2017}}</ref>
In 2016, Pamies partnered with youtuber Juan Pablo Jaramillo and Juana Martinez in a campaign to defend diversity and tolerance.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Famosos 'youtubers' publican video de su visita a Costa Rica| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''nacion.com''| date = | url =http://www.nacion.com/viva/television/famosos-youtubers-publican-video-de-su-visita-a-costa-rica/GHMH6E5S4RH5HMEXMQETPHFX3U/story/ | accessdate =21 December 2017}}</ref> The campaign was called ''#EDUCATETOLOVE'' and the video was presented in Congress.<ref>{{cite news | last =Ed | first =Salvato | title =Oriol Pamies' Top 6 Things To Do in Barcelona| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''towleroad.com''| date =26 September 2015 | url =http://www.towleroad.com/2015/09/oriol-palmies-top-6-things-barcelona/ | accessdate =21 December 2017}}</ref> In 2017, Pamies led Moovz to become the official social network of [[WorldPride|Madrid World Pride 2017]].<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Intervista al Sexy Oriol Pamies di Moovz| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''quiikymagazine.com''| date =26 November 2015 | url =http://www.quiikymagazine.com/intervista-al-sexy-oriol-pamies-di-moovz/ | accessdate =21 December 2017}}</ref>
Pamies has taken part in conferences, presenting topics related to entrepreneurship, online marketing and activism.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Speakers 2017| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''iglta.org''| date = | url =https://www.iglta.org/convention/program/speakers-2017/ | accessdate =21 December 2017}}</ref>
===Tourism industry=== Through his work at Moovz, Pamies developed marketing strategies to position tourist destinations as LGBT friendly.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Los 5 influencers gays más importantes del momento| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''cromosomax.com''| date =16 March 2017 | url =https://www.cromosomax.com/35631-los-5-influencers-gays-mas-importantes-del-momento | accessdate =21 December 2017}}</ref> In 2015 and through a partnership with [[Tel Aviv]] Municipality, he was behind a project that broadcast through the app the Tel Aviv Pride Parade.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Pride of Tel Aviv| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''alvarolaforet.com''| date = | url =http://www.alvarolaforet.com/pride-of-tel-aviv/ | accessdate =21 December 2017}}</ref> In 2016, he advocated and promoted Israel through an interview at the Spanish Magazine Shangay.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Oriol Pamies : "Todos tenemos un activista dentro| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''superhypemagazine.com''| date = | url =https://www.superhypemagazine.com/cultura-hype/2016/6/17/oriol-pamies | accessdate =21 December 2017}}</ref> In May 2017, during the annual convention of [[International Gay and Lesbian Travel Association]] (IGLTA) in [[St. Petersburg, Florida]], he delivered the first keynote in Spanish.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Colombia: Encuentro de Periodismo para la Diversidad| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''sinetiquetas.org''| date =20 June 2016 | url =http://sinetiquetas.org/2016/06/30/colombia-1er-encuentro-periodismo-la-diversidad/ | accessdate =21 December 2017}}</ref> In September 2017 in [[Bogotá]], he took part at the International Congress of Social Mobility and Right to the City, organised by the City Hall, where he presented a case study on how the [[Pride parade|Gay Pride Parade]] can contribute at the positioning and International promotion of a city as an LGBT friendly destination.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =MOOVZ, EL FACEBOOK DE LOS GAYS| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''jetset.com.co''| date = | url =http://www.jetset.com.co/edicion-impresa/temas-revista-jetset/articulo/moovz-el-facebook-de-los-gays/152508 | accessdate =21 December 2017}}</ref>
==Personal life== Pamies is gay and has expressed his desire to have kids in several occasions. He came out at the age of 19.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =#coming out Gay Mormon In Texas Comes Out, Wants To Meet Davey Wavey| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''queerty.com''| date = | url =https://www.queerty.com/gay-mormon-in-texas-comes-out-wants-to-meet-davey-wavey-20141010 | accessdate =21 December 2017}}</ref>
==Awards and recognitions== In 2017, [[MTV]] invited Pamies to take part in the project ''Out in 60'', a project where celebrities and influencers shared their coming out story in 60 seconds.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =#TBT: Oriol Pamies| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''winq.com''| date = | url =http://www.winq.com/2015/04/tbt-oriol-pamies/ | accessdate =21 December 2017}}</ref> According to the Spanish portal "Cromosoma X", Pamies is one of most important LGBT influencers of the moment in 2017.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =LGBT social network Moovz backs 'Love is Love' campaign| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''pinknews.co.uk''| date = | url =http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2016/05/05/lgbt-social-network-moovz-backs-love-is-love-campaign/ | accessdate =21 December 2017}}</ref> In 2017, he was revealed as one of the "top 20 bachelors of the year" by [[Attitude (magazine)|Attitude Magazine]].<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =REVEALED: ATTITUDE'S TOP 20 BACHELORS OF THE YEAR| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''attitude.co.uk''| date = | url =https://attitude.co.uk/article/14347/revealed-attitudes-top-20-bachelors-of-the-year/ | accessdate =21 December 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

'''Peter Barr''' (1826–1909) was a Scottish nurseryman and merchant, best known for [[daffodil]]s.<ref name="ODNB">{{cite ODNB|id=96755|first=M. C.|last=Curthoys|title=Barr, Peter}}</ref>
==Life== He was born in [[Govan]], Lanarkshire, the son of James Barr, a mill owner, and his wife, Mary Findlay. From a seed shop in [[Glasgow]], he moved to a seed merchant's in [[Newry]], and then went into business in 1852 in a partnership in [[Worcester]], concentrating on [[bulb]]s.<ref name="ODNB"/>
After a change of partners, Barr in 1860 was in the bulb trade in [[King Street, St James's]] in London. He was known for his catalogues, and for gaining the interest of British gardeners in daffodils, then neglected, inspired by the work of [[John Parkinson (botanist)|John Parkinson]] in the 17th century.<ref name="ODNB"/>
==Legacy== The Peter Barr Memorial Cup is awarded each year by the [[Royal Horticultural Society]] to somebody who has done good work in relation to daffodils.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rhs.org.uk/plants/pdfs/plant-registration-forms/barr-cup-recipients.pdf |title=THE PETER BARR MEMORIAL CUP |accessdate=6 August 2018 |last= |first= |coauthors= |date=3 November 2016 |work= |publisher=Royal Horitcultural Society}}</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist}}
